course.title: Around the World in 80 Blunders: The Russian Baltic Fleet's Epic Fail
course.description: Embark on a hilariously tragic voyage with the Tsar's Baltic Fleet during the Russo-Japanese War! This course charts the unbelievable journey of a fleet plagued by misfortune, incompetence, and a severe shortage of common sense. From mistaking British fishermen for Japanese destroyers to the logistical nightmare of coaling obsolete battleships across the globe, you'll learn why this expedition is a textbook example of 'what not to do.'
learningObjectives: Understand the basic geopolitical context and causes of the Russo-Japanese War
Recount the major (and most comical) blunders committed by the Baltic Fleet during its voyage
Identify the key figures involved and their (often questionable) decisions
Analyze the logistical, technical, and human factors contributing to the fleet's disastrous performance
Appreciate the darkly humorous side of historical events and the importance of learning from past mistakes
Explain the ultimate fate of the fleet at the Battle of Tsushima and its impact on the war
prerequisites: Basic understanding of world map geography
Interest in naval or military history

1.1.title: Why Are We Even Here? - The Russo-Japanese Powder Keg
1.1.introduction: In the early 1900s, two expanding empires collided in a remote corner of the world. Russia, pushing eastward in search of warm-water ports, and Japan, flexing its newly modernized muscles, were on a collision course that would lead to one of history's most farcical military expeditions.

content.value: Our story begins with Imperial Russia's insatiable appetite for expansion. For centuries, Russia had been pushing outward in all directions, but particularly eastward across Siberia. By the late 19th century, they had reached the Pacific and established Vladivostok as their eastern naval base. But there was a problem: Vladivostok freezes over in winter, rendering it useless for part of the year. The solution? Find a warm-water port further south!
Russia's eastward expansion was driven by the quest for a year-round warm-water port, leading them to covet Port Arthur (now Lüshun) in Manchuria.

Meanwhile, Japan had undergone a remarkable transformation. After centuries of isolation, the Meiji Restoration of 1868 led to rapid modernization and industrialization. By 1900, Japan had built a modern navy modeled on the British Royal Navy, with well-trained crews and up-to-date warships. The Japanese, too, had ambitions on the Asian mainland, especially in Korea and Manchuria.

Russian Interests -> Warm-water ports -> Port Arthur in Manchuria
Japanese Interests -> Regional dominance -> Influence in Korea and Manchuria
Both nations -> Competing for same territory -> Inevitable conflict

The flashpoint was Port Arthur, a strategically located harbor on the Liaodong Peninsula. Russia had leased it from China in 1898, built railways connecting it to the Trans-Siberian Railroad, and stationed their Pacific Fleet there. Japan saw this as a direct threat to their own interests in the region.

Diplomatic efforts failed spectacularly when Tsar Nicholas II dismissed the Japanese as 'little yellow monkeys' who would never dare to challenge the might of Imperial Russia. This racist underestimation would prove catastrophic. When negotiations broke down, Japan launched a surprise attack on Port Arthur in February 1904, starting the Russo-Japanese War with a decisive blow.

The war began with a series of humiliating defeats for Russia. The Japanese navy bottled up the Russian Pacific Fleet in Port Arthur and began a siege of the port city. On land, Japanese forces defeated the Russians at the Battle of Yalu River and continued to push them back. By August 1904, it was clear that Russia's forces in the Far East were in serious trouble.
Japan's surprise attack and early victories shocked the world and humiliated Russia, prompting Tsar Nicholas II to make the fateful decision to send the Baltic Fleet halfway around the world.

Enter Tsar Nicholas II's brilliant 'Plan B': Send the Baltic Fleet—Russia's main naval force stationed in the Baltic Sea—all the way around the world to save the day! Never mind that this would require sailing more than 18,000 miles (that's about 3/4 of the way around the globe), mostly through waters controlled by potentially hostile powers, with limited coaling stations, in a fleet that included ships dating from the American Civil War era. What could possibly go wrong?

Imagine you are an advisor to Tsar Nicholas II in 1904. Draft a one-paragraph memo either supporting or opposing the plan to send the Baltic Fleet to the Far East. Include at least three specific factors that influenced your recommendation.

Consider how nationalist pride and racial prejudice influenced Russian decision-making. How might the history of the Russo-Japanese War have been different if Russian leaders had accurately assessed Japanese capabilities? Have there been other instances in history where underestimating an opponent led to disaster?

1.1.summary: The Russo-Japanese War erupted from competing imperial ambitions in East Asia, with Russia seeking warm-water ports and Japan asserting regional dominance. After suffering humiliating early defeats, Tsar Nicholas II made the fateful decision to send the Baltic Fleet on an 18,000-mile journey to turn the tide of war—a decision born more of desperation and hubris than sound military strategy.
1.1.nextSteps: Next, we'll meet the ships and men of the Baltic Fleet, a motley collection of vessels and sailors about to embark on one of history's most ill-fated naval expeditions.

2.1.title: The Dogger Bank Incident: Fishermen or Fiends?
2.1.introduction: Just days into their epic journey, the Russian Baltic Fleet managed to achieve the remarkable feat of nearly starting a war with Great Britain—a country they weren't even fighting. The Dogger Bank Incident of October 1904 would go down in history as one of the most bizarre friendly fire incidents ever recorded, when a jumpy Russian fleet opened fire on innocent British fishing trawlers in the North Sea.

content.value: Setting out from the Baltic in October 1904, the Russian fleet was already on edge. Rumors were rampant that Japanese torpedo boats had somehow infiltrated European waters and were lying in wait to ambush them. These rumors were, of course, completely absurd—the Japanese had neither the range nor any reason to send torpedo boats thousands of miles from home when the Russians were conveniently sailing toward them anyway. But paranoia doesn't listen to logic.
The Russian fleet was gripped by paranoia about Japanese torpedo boats in European waters, despite the geographical impossibility of such a threat.

On the night of October 21-22, 1904, the fleet was passing through the North Sea near the Dogger Bank, a shallow area frequented by fishing boats. It was a dark, somewhat foggy night. The Russian ships were sailing with their lights extinguished to avoid detection by those mythical Japanese torpedo boats.

Around midnight, Russian lookouts spotted the Hull fishing fleet—about 30 British trawlers from Kingston-upon-Hull going about their peaceful business of catching cod. In the darkness, the exhausted and nervous Russian lookouts somehow transformed these slow-moving fishing boats into Japanese torpedo craft on an attack run.

In the ensuing chaos, the flagship Knyaz Suvorov signaled 'torpedo boats attack!' and opened fire. Soon, multiple Russian battleships were blazing away with all guns at the bewildered fishermen. The battleship Oryol alone fired over 500 shells—though thankfully, Russian gunnery proved as inaccurate against unarmed fishermen as it would later against the Japanese fleet. One trawler, the Crane, was sunk, two more were seriously damaged, two fishermen were killed, and six others wounded.
The Russians fired hundreds of shells at the fishing fleet, sank one trawler (the Crane), damaged others, killed two fishermen, and wounded six more.

But wait, it gets worse! Some Russian ships, in their panic, started firing at each other. The cruiser Aurora was hit by several shells from other Russian vessels and had several sailors wounded. Meanwhile, much of the fleet continued sailing, abandoning damaged fishing boats without rendering assistance to survivors—a serious violation of maritime law.

Russian Paranoia -> Sighting of fishing boats -> Misidentification as Japanese torpedo boats -> Opening fire -> Hitting British trawlers -> Hitting own ships -> Sailing away without rendering aid -> International incident -> Diplomatic crisis

When news reached Britain, the public was outraged. The incident was dubbed 'The Russian Outrage' in newspapers. The British government mobilized the powerful Royal Navy, and for a few tense days, war between Russia and Britain seemed entirely possible. This would have been especially awkward since Britain was allied with Japan through the Anglo-Japanese Alliance of 1902.

British Admiral Sir John Fisher, upon hearing of the incident, reportedly said he could have the Russian fleet on the bottom of the sea by the weekend. Given the Royal Navy's overwhelming superiority, this was less a boast and more a statement of fact. One British newspaper captured the mood with the headline: "IS IT WAR?"

You are a Russian sailor aboard the battleship Oryol during the Dogger Bank Incident. Write a brief entry in your personal diary describing what you witnessed that night and your thoughts about what happened. Include details about the confusion, the firing, and your concerns about the rest of the voyage.

In a darkly humorous twist, after finally ceasing fire on the fishing boats, the Russians sent a report back to St. Petersburg claiming they had successfully fought off a Japanese attack in the North Sea. The Russian Admiralty actually congratulated them on their vigilance before the truth emerged!

The Dogger Bank Incident highlights how paranoia and poor training can lead to tragic consequences. Consider how confirmation bias (seeing what you expect to see) played a role in this incident. How might similar psychological factors affect military or crisis decision-making today?

2.1.summary: The Dogger Bank Incident exemplified the Russian Baltic Fleet's paranoia and incompetence, as they mistook British fishing trawlers for Japanese torpedo boats and opened fire, killing fishermen and nearly starting a war with Britain. This international incident foreshadowed the fleet's continuing problems with training, discipline, and leadership that would plague their entire journey.
2.1.nextSteps: In our next sprint, we'll examine the diplomatic fallout from this disaster and how Russia narrowly avoided war with the British Empire.

4.2.title: Crossing the 'T': A Bad Day to be Russian
4.2.introduction: On May 27, 1905, after an eight-month journey covering 18,000 nautical miles, the Russian Baltic Fleet finally met its destiny in the Tsushima Strait. What followed was not just a defeat but an annihilation so complete that naval historians still study it today—though usually not for examples of what to do right.

content.value: Dawn broke misty on May 27, 1905, as the Russian fleet steamed in two columns through the Tsushima Strait between Korea and Japan. After months of tension, false alarms, and paranoia, this day would bring the real thing: actual contact with the Japanese navy they had traveled so far to fight.

At approximately 7:00 am, lookouts on the Russian flagship spotted a Japanese ship. Unlike the phantom Japanese torpedo boats in the North Sea, this one was real—the Japanese auxiliary cruiser Shinano Maru had spotted the Russians and immediately radioed Admiral Togo. The Russians, observing the Japanese ship seemingly dash away, realized with dread that their position had been reported. Any hope of sneaking through to Vladivostok undetected was gone.
The Japanese had wireless communication between ships; the Russians largely did not. This technological edge allowed the Japanese to coordinate their fleet movements with unprecedented precision.

Admiral Rozhestvensky's battle plan, to the extent one existed, seems to have been simply to break through to Vladivostok while inflicting whatever damage possible on any Japanese ships that tried to stop him. It was less a tactical masterpiece and more a desperate hope to bulldoze through to safety.

Japanese Battle Plan -> Wireless communications -> Coordinated movements -> 'Crossing the T' maneuver -> Concentrated firepower -> Maximum damage
Russian Battle Plan -> Limited communications -> Confusion and disarray -> Scattered response -> Diluted firepower -> Minimal effectiveness

At 1:40 pm, the main Japanese fleet appeared on the horizon. Admiral Togo executed a risky but brilliant maneuver—turning his flagship Mikasa and following ships in sequence across the path of the Russian fleet, despite exposing each ship briefly to the full Russian line during the turn. This created the classic naval tactic known as 'Crossing the T.'

'Crossing the T' is a naval tactic where one fleet crosses in front of the enemy's line, allowing all ships to fire their broadsides while the enemy can only use forward guns. It's like being able to punch someone with both fists while they can only jab with one finger.

When Admiral Togo successfully crossed the Russian 'T,' the Russians found themselves in a nightmare scenario. While each Japanese ship could bring most of its guns to bear on the leading Russian ships, the Russians could only fire with their forward guns, and ships further back in the column couldn't effectively fire at all without risking hitting their own vessels. It was like bringing a spoon to a gunfight.

The difference in gunnery was immediately apparent. The Japanese had practiced exhaustively and used range-finding equipment effectively. The Russians, who had barely had opportunity to practice during their long voyage, were using outdated methods and many of their shells were duds due to poor manufacturing and storage.

The Russians fired 8,604 shells from their main guns during the battle and scored approximately 5 significant hits—a hit rate of about 0.06%. The Japanese fired 6,240 shells and scored about 243 significant hits—a hit rate of 3.89%. The Japanese were literally 65 times more accurate than their opponents.

The flagship Knyaz Suvorov was quickly targeted and hit multiple times. Within an hour of the battle starting, she was a burning wreck, her steering damaged and most of her guns knocked out. Admiral Rozhestvensky himself was wounded by shrapnel to the head and effectively out of the fight—though given how the battle was going, his tactical guidance was hardly being missed.

Meanwhile, the hapless auxiliary cruiser Kamchatka—famous for its misidentification of British fishing trawlers as Japanese torpedo boats in the Dogger Bank incident—maintained its reputation for chaos. In the confusion of battle, it reportedly signaled that it was being attacked by the Japanese from all directions, when in fact there were no Japanese ships near it. It later mistakenly fired on Russian vessels, contributing to the friendly fire confusion.

You are a Japanese naval officer observing the battle through binoculars. Write a brief report of what you see happening to the Russian fleet during the first hour of engagement. Include specific observations about their formation, response to Japanese fire, and any tactical mistakes you notice.

The Battle of Tsushima highlights the importance of training, technology, and tactical doctrine. Consider how the Japanese victory represented not just superior ships or weapons, but better preparation, leadership, and execution. What lessons might modern military forces take from this historic engagement?

quiz.explanation: The Japanese hit rate was about 3.89% compared to the Russian rate of 0.06%, making them approximately 65 times more accurate.

4.2.summary: The Battle of Tsushima demonstrated the vast gulf in training, technology, and tactics between the Japanese and Russian fleets. Admiral Togo's brilliant 'Crossing the T' maneuver, combined with vastly superior Japanese gunnery and communication, turned the battle into a one-sided annihilation of the Russian fleet that had traveled eight months and 18,000 miles only to meet disaster.
4.2.nextSteps: In our next sprint, we'll witness the final destruction of the Russian Baltic Fleet and examine the staggering casualties and captures that made this one of history's most decisive naval battles.
